author: Staff Reporter
text:
Snakes are drawn to the tar roads during the winter months: biologist

Vehicular traffic along T. Kalathur to Manachanallur has been responsible for killing many snakes in the area, according to a recent study.

Q. Ashoka Chakkaravarthy, wildlife biologist and assistant professor of Environmental Science, Department Of Foundation Courses, St. Joseph’s College, who conducted the study, said most of the killing occurred in the monsoon months from November to January, along a 27-km stretch of road. “The most troubling sight was to find snakes that are arboreal (tree-dwelling) in nature lying dead by the roadside,” said Mr. Chakkaravarthy.

Reptile on road

“If the canopy of trees lining the road had not been disturbed, they would have crossed over without coming down. “In the monsoon, post-monsoon, and winter months the road is a lot warmer than the forest floor so they must have been drawn to the tar roads,” he said.

Another reason for the high snake mortality rate could be due to the breeding season that coincides with the monsoon, said Mr. Chakkaravarthy. Species such as common krait, Russell’s viper, saw-scaled viper and rat snakes are most at risk, if not from traffic, then from being illed when they enter human habitations, said Mr. Chakkaravarthy.

“Reptiles and amphibians are known to be the most affected by vehicular traffic, but there is very little information available on such accidents,” he added.
title: Roads turn minefields for snakes near Manachallur
